title: Souris, Manitoba
text:
Souris is an unincorporated urban community in the <a href="Municipality%20of%20Souris%20%E2%80%93%20Glenwood">Municipality of Souris – Glenwood</a> within the <a href="Provinces%20and%20territories%20of%20Canada">Canadian province</a> of <a href="Manitoba">Manitoba</a> that held town status prior to January 1, 2015 (2016 population: 1,876). It is located within the municipality at the confluence of <a href="Plum%20Creek%20%28Manitoba%29">Plum Creek</a> and <a href="Souris%20River">Souris River</a>, from which it takes its name. Before 1882, the town was called Plum Creek. The community is home to Canada's longest historic cable-stayed footbridge (), known as the Swinging Bridge, which spans the Souris River that divides the community. The Swinging Bridge was built in 1904 as a means of transportation over the Souris River. Residents of Souris are referred to as Sourisites.
Attractions.
The Souris Swinging Bridge was destroyed in the 1976 flood and again in the flood of 2011. A new, higher, swinging bridge opened during the summer of 2013. A new swimming pool was constructed in 2010 and is located in Victoria Park, along with numerous walking trails and a bird sanctuary known for its flock of peacocks. The Rock Shop sells many rocks and all of different sizes and varieties.
Sports.
Souris is home to the Southwest Cougars, an <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a> team which plays in the <a href="Manitoba%20Midget%20%27AAA%27%20Hockey%20League">Manitoba Midget 'AAA' Hockey League</a>. It is also home of the Souris (SW) Sabres, which is part of the school program. It includes; hockey, basketball, volleyball, football, and rugby.
Another local hockey team is the Souris Elks, which is a senior team in the Tiger Hills Hockey League.
